channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Lawmakers in Crimea Move Swiftly to Split From Ukraine
item.description: The regional Parliament said Crimea was an independent state no longer subject to Ukrainian laws, while the Parliament in Kiev approved the call-up of thousands of reservists to the military.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: After 96.77 percent of Crimeans voted for secession, officials in Simferopol declared Monday a day off from work.

item.title: Malaysia Backtracks on When Airliner’s Communications Were Disabled
item.description: The authorities said Monday that they could not pinpoint precisely when the system was turned off, reversing earlier assertions.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRISTOPHER BUCKLEY
item.media:description: On Monday, Hishammuddin Hussein, Malaysia’s acting minister of transportation, showed two maps with corridors of the last known possible position of the plane.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Catholic Bishop Who Spent Decades in Prison Dies in Shanghai
item.description: Bishop Joseph Fan Zhongliang, who was imprisoned for more than two decades in China and spent his final years under house arrest, died on Sunday at age 95, a Roman Catholic organization said.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: The Cardinal Kung Foundation/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Obama to Meet With Palestinian Leader as Diplomacy Deadline Looms
item.description: President Obama will meet President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Monday, amid signs that the peace process has hit a roadblock over Israel’s insistence that the Palestinians formally recognize it as a Jewish state.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: U.S. Navy SEALs Take Control of Diverted Oil Tanker
item.description: Navy commandos seized an oil tanker in the Mediterranean waters southeast of Cyprus, thwarting an attempt by a breakaway Libyan militia to sell its contents on the black market, the Pentagon said.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: India Ink: Indian Play About Muslim Identity Canceled Over Fears of Violence
item.description: “Ali J,” which explores what it means to be Muslim in India, has had performances dropped across the country after a Hindu group said the play would incite religious hatred.
item.dc:creator: By KAVITHA RAO
item.media:description: Karthik Kumar, actor and director of the play "Ali J," said he would upload the play to the Internet.

item.title: Amid Mayoral Missteps, Irish Eyes Are Rolling in New York City
item.description: Mayor Bill de Blasio often celebrates the multiethnic fabric of New York, but for the city’s Irish, his young mayoralty has been perceived as a series of slights and indignities.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM and NIKITA STEWART
item.media:description: Mayor Bill de Blasio marched in the St. Pat’s for All parade in Sunnyside, Queens, but will boycott the St. Patrick’s Day Parade on Fifth Avenue.

item.title: India Ink: In Varanasi, a Lifetime Spent in a World of Death
item.description: In a city where Hindus come to die, Yamuna Devi, a member of a century-old untouchable caste, oversees the earthly end of a Hindu’s spiritual journey.
item.dc:creator: By SHANTANU GUHA RAY
item.media:description: Yamuna Devi, a female Dom, whose role is considered integral in the cremation of dead bodies, at the Manikarnika Ghat in Varanasi, India.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese News Agency Slams Delays in Search for Jet
item.description: China’s state-run news agency, Xinhua, criticized the Malaysian authorities, saying that the search for the missing aircraft, with mostly Chinese passengers aboard, has wasted time and resources.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: 9/11 Architect Says Bin Laden’s Son-in-Law Had No Role in Qaeda Military Operations
item.description: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed suggested that Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, who is on trial in Manhattan, was enlisted to make fiery speeches for Al Qaeda because he was “an eloquent, spellbinding speaker.”
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Morocco Journal: Gender Inequality in Morocco Continues, Despite Amendments to Family Law
item.description: Human rights groups said some judges were reluctant to apply the law and found ways around it, or were oblivious to its amendments.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AIDA ALAMI
item.media:description: Women rallied in support of Amina Filali, who committed suicide after being forced to marry a man who allegedly raped her.

item.title: Facts Elusive in Kabul Death of Swedish Reporter
item.description: Afghan officials, however, continued to back a theory that Western intelligence agents were to blame in the death of Nils Horner.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Afghan police officers monitored the site of a deadly attack on Nils Horner, a Swedish Radio reporter. The case is rife with speculation but short on evidence, save for a surveillance video.

item.title: Scores Killed in Raids on Central Nigeria Villages
item.description: The police confirmed Friday’s raids on three villages in Kaduna State, where violence is driven by decades-old land disputes between semi-nomadic communities and settled farmers.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: News Analysis: Global Crises Put Obama’s Strategy of Caution to the Test
item.description: Turmoil in Ukraine and Syria is challenging President Obama’s attempts to change the way the United States deals with its overseas adversaries.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crimeans in Simferopol celebrated a vote on Sunday to break from Ukraine and join Russia.

item.title: Ola L. Mize, Korean War Hero, Dies at 82
item.description: He initially refused the Medal of Honor, the nation’s highest military award for valor, but finally accepted it on behalf of his men, a recognition presented to him by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in September 1954.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Retired Army Col. Ola Lee Mize received the Medal of Honor for his actions in the Korean War.

item.title: Unskilled and Destitute Are Hiring Targets for Fukushima Cleanup
item.description: The operator of the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant has left the complex cleanup to a poorly trained work force that has made some dangerous missteps.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fukushima Daiichi workers boarding a bus to take them to the damaged nuclear plant. The workers are housed in a village where, they said, there was little to do.

item.title: As U.S. Looks for Terror Links in Plane Case, Malaysia Rejects Extensive Help
item.description: With no obvious motive apparent, American investigators are considering a wide range of possibilities but caution that all remain merely speculative.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Canada Explores G.M. Link to Accidents
item.description: Canada is looking into whether a fatal crash last June is related to the automaker’s faulty ignition switches.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: The Lede: Russia Could Still Turn U.S. ‘Into Radioactive Dust,’ News Anchor in Moscow Reminds Viewers
item.description: One of Russia’s most influential television hosts appeared on the evening news Sunday to remind viewers that Russia is still “the only country in the world capable of turning the U.S.A. into radioactive dust.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Russia's ambassador to the United Nations, Vitaly I. Churkin, was confronted by his American counterpart, Samantha Power, on Saturday before a Security Council meeting on the status of Crimea.

item.title: Syrian Government Forces Seize Town in a Deep Blow to Opposition
item.description: Government forces, backed by Hezbollah fighters, took control of Yabrud, a critical transit point for militants, refugees and arms heading in and out of Lebanon.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Syrian government soldiers in the town of Yabrud on Sunday after the army seized full control of the rebel bastion.

item.title: Wave of Sexual Abuse Allegations for Private Boys’ Schools in Britain
item.description: Prompted by publicity surrounding recent child abuse scandals, dozens of British men have come forward about molestation they say they suffered at expensive private schools.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Palestinians Split in Gaza as Hamas Blocks Fatah Rally
item.description: The conflict is a sign of the enduring schism between Hamas and the Palestinian Authority, a factor that further complicates American-brokered Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Art World’s Cream Rises at Maastricht
item.description: The offerings at this year’s blue-chip Maastricht art fair, in the Netherlands, stretch from the ancient to the modern.
item.dc:creator: By CAROL VOGEL
item.media:description: “The Supper at Emmaus” by Bernardo Strozzi (1581-1664).

item.title: Crimea Votes to Secede From Ukraine as Russian Troops Keep Watch
item.description: An overwhelming majority voted on Sunday to leave Ukraine in a referendum that Western leaders have declared illegal and vowed to punish with sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman cast her ballot in the Crimean referendum on Sunday in Simferopol, Ukraine.

item.title: Timing of Report by Flight’s Pilot Focuses Inquiry
item.description: The pilot did not mention any trouble, a senior Malaysian official said, reinforcing theories that one or both of the pilots may have been involved in diverting the plane.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A Malaysian soldier patrolled an area of the airport in Kuala Lumpur where passengers have written messages for the people aboard the missing plane and their loved ones.
